Since the simulation results of Section III showed that thelarge deviations of money growth rates from normal appear to account for muchof the recovery of real output between 1933 and 1937 and between 1938 and1942, it is possible to conclude that independent monetary developmentsaccount for the bulk of the recovery from the Great Depression.
B. Transmission MechanismThe usual way that loose monetary policy is thought to affect realoutput is through real interest rates: an increase in the money growth ratelowers real interest rates, and this in turn stimulates interest—sensitive
spending by lowering the cost of borrowing or by reducing the opportunity costof spending. To see if this usual mechanism could have been operating in thesecond half of the 1930s, it is necessary to look at the behavior of interestrates and interest—sensitive spending.Interest Rates.
